MUMBAI, Dec 21 (IFR) - Future Retail's bonds and shares have surged after India's antitrust agency suspended Amazon's 2019 deal with the group, potentially clearing the way for an asset sale to Reliance Retail.

The Competition Commission of India's suspension of the deal on Friday has put a dent in the US e-commerce giant's attempts to block the sale of Future Group's retail assets to Reliance Industries’ retail arm.

Future Retail's US$500m 5.6% bonds due in January 2025 have rallied by 3 cents to the 55 level since December 17 to yield 29.489%, while its shares have rallied 17% in the past two trading sessions, according to Refinitiv data. The dollar bonds touched an all-time low of 50 cents on December 13.

The regulator ruled that Amazon suppressed information while seeking regulatory approval two years ago for its US$200m investment in Future Group, India's second largest retailer.

For months, Amazon successfully used the terms of that deal to block the attempt to sell the retail assets for US$3.4bn to Reliance Retail, Amazon's biggest rival in the Indian retail sector.

Future Retail has been under increased financial pressure after India's supreme court suspended the proposed acquisition by Reliance Industries in early August following the legal challenges by Amazon. 

The regulator said Amazon will be given time to submit information again to seek approvals, but Reuters reported on Monday that Future Retail was unlikely to cooperate with Amazon if it tries to reapply for antitrust clearance.

(Reporting by Krishna Merchant; Editing by David Holland)
